message_1: What is the structure of a given unknown organic compound using IR spectroscopy?
message_2:
As a chemist, I can help you interpret the IR spectroscopy data to determine the structure of an unknown organic compound. However, I will need the actual IR spectrum or the significant peak values and their corresponding wavenumbers (cm⁻¹) to provide a detailed analysis.

In general, IR spectroscopy is a powerful technique for identifying functional groups in organic compounds. Here are some common functional groups and their characteristic IR absorption bands:

1. O-H (alcohol or phenol) - broad peak around 3200-3600 cm⁻¹
2. N-H (amine) - sharp peak around 3300-3500 cm⁻¹
3. C-H (alkane) - peaks around 2800-3000 cm⁻¹
4. C=C (alkene) - peaks around 1600-1680 cm⁻¹
5. C=O (carbonyl) - sharp peak around 1700-1750 cm⁻¹
6. C≡C (alkyne) - peak around 2100-2260 cm⁻¹
7. C≡N (nitrile) - peak around 2210-2260 cm⁻¹
8. C-O (ether or ester) - peak around 1000-1300 cm⁻¹

Please provide the IR spectrum or the significant peak values, and I will help you determine the structure of the unknown organic compound.
